prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: J0331 - FIR-bright
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This source was detected by Herschel/SPIRE at 250, 350 and 500 microns.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
This source was detected by Herschel/SPIRE at 250, 350 and 500 microns.
From the Herschel data, we estimate it's FIR luminosity to be L_FIR >2x10^{13} L_Sun (reference [27]). The Herschel data was used to estimate the continuum flux of our targets in ALMA's band 7. By extrapolating the best-fit FIR templates, we obtained conservative estimates of flux densities of ~10-12 mJy at 330 Ghz.
The central regions of each extended target, of about 1x1 arcsec^2, would be probed by about 10 beams. We thus estimate continuum flux densities of ~1-1.2 mJy per beam.
The width of the [CII] 157.7 emission line is expected to be several 100 km/s (see, e.g., references [22,33,35]). Thus, we selected the TDM correlator mode (an effective bandwidth of 1875 MHz), with a spectral resolution of ~28 km/s. The 3 additional basebands will probe the line-free continuum emission.
The flux of the [CII] line was estimated by assuming L_{[CII]}/L_FIR = 3x10^{-4} (e.g., reference [23]) and a line width of FWHM=300 km/s. This translates to flux densities of about 30 and 5 mJy, or ~3-3.6 and ~0.5 mJy/beam, for the FIR-bright and FIR-faint sources,
The requirement to resolve the host systems at kpc scales dictates the usage of the C34-4 array configuration, providing an angular resolution of ~0.3" (~2 kpc at z~4.7).
The width of the [CII] 157.7 emission line is expected to be several 100 km/s. Thus, we selected the TDM correlator mode (an effective bandwidth of 1875 MHz), with a spectral resolution of ~35 km/s. The 3 additional basebands will probe the line-free continuum emission.
The flux of the [CII] line was estimated by assuming L_{[CII]}/L_FIR = 3x10^{-4} (e.g., [23]) and a line width of FWHM=300 km/s. This translates to flux densities of about 30 and 5 mJy, or ~3-3.6 and ~0.5 mJy/beam, for the FIR-bright and FIR-faint sources, respectively.

The central regions of each extended target, of about 1x1 arcsec^2, would be probed by about 10 beams. We thus estimate continuum flux densities of ~1-1.2 mJy per beam.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: J1511 - FIR-bright
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This source was detected by Herschel/SPIRE at 250, 350 and 500 microns.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
This source was detected by Herschel/SPIRE at 250, 350 and 500 microns.
From the Herschel data, we estimate it's FIR luminosity to be L_FIR >2x10^{13} L_Sun (reference [27]). The Herschel data was used to estimate the continuum flux of our targets in ALMA's band 7. By extrapolating the best-fit FIR templates, we obtained conservative estimates of flux densities of ~10-12 mJy at 330 Ghz.
The central regions of each extended target, of about 1x1 arcsec^2, would be probed by about 10 beams. We thus estimate continuum flux densities of ~1-1.2 mJy per beam.
The requirement to resolve the host systems at kpc scales dictates the usage of the C34-4 array configuration, providing an angular resolution of ~0.3" (~2 kpc at z~4.7).

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: J0923 - FIR-faint
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This source was NOT detected by Herschel/SPIRE (at 250, 350 and 500 microns).

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
This source was NOT detected by Herschel/SPIRE (at 250, 350 and 500 microns).
From our stacking analysis of the available Herschel data, we estimate it's FIR luminosity to be L_FIR ~ 4.5x10^{12} L_Sun (reference [27]). The Herschel data was used to estimate the continuum flux of our targets in ALMA's band 7. By extrapolating the best-fit FIR templates, we obtained conservative estimates of flux densities of at least ~3 mJy at 330 Ghz.
The central regions of each extended target, of about 1x1 arcsec^2, would be probed by about 10 beams. We thus estimate continuum flux densities of at least ~0.3 mJy per beam.
The requirement to resolve the host systems at kpc scales dictates the usage of the C34-4 array configuration, providing an angular resolution of ~0.3" (~2 kpc at z~4.7).
The width of the [CII] 157.7 emission line is expected to be several 100 km/s (e.g., references [22,33,35]). Thus, we selected the TDM correlator mode (an effective bandwidth of 1875 MHz), with a spectral resolution of ~28 km/s. The 3 additional basebands will probe the line-free continuum emission.
The flux of the [CII] line was estimated by assuming L_{[CII]}/L_FIR = 3x10^{-4} (e.g., reference [23]) and a line width of FWHM=300 km/s. This translates to flux densities of about 5 mJy, or ~0.5 mJy/beam, for this "FIR-faint" source.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose a pilot study to probe the host systems of fast-growing Super-Massive Black Holes (SMBHs) at z~4.8, which would likely become the most massive BHs known (M_BH>=10^{10} M_sun) before z~4. Our Herschel observations show that these sources are hosted in two types of extreme star-forming (SF) galaxies: one with SFR>2000 M_sun/yr, indicative of major mergers as the common triggering mechanism for both SF and AGN activity, and another group with SFR~450 M_sun/yr, that may be related to secular evolution, or to AGN-driven feedback. The proposed ALMA observations will test this scenario, by probing the distribution of gas and SF, at scales of ~2 kpc, in the host systems of three objects in each group. The luminous [CII]157.7 um line, which may be detected in most of the sources, would probe the dynamics of the hosts and will provide a clear test for the occurrence of major mergers. The [CII] line would also allow us to estimate the dynamical masses of the hosts, and thus estimate the M_BH/M_dyn ratio at z~4.8. Thus, ALMA can probe the relevance of major mergers, possible feedback or secular growth for a well-defined sample of high-redshift, fast-growing BHs and host galaxies.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:keyword: Luminous and Ultra-Luminous Infra-Red Galaxies (LIRG & ULIRG)
